# Music in Morocco — Full Knowledge Reference
# Published by Slow Morocco · https://www.slowmorocco.com
# Last updated: 2026

## Overview
Music in Morocco (musicinmorocco.com) is a comprehensive reference for Moroccan performance traditions spanning music, dance, and ritual. The site documents 24 artists, 18 performance forms, 18 instruments, 15 festivals, 19 cities, and 17 thematic concepts.

## Performance Traditions

### Gnawa (كناوة)
Category: Ritual. Origin: Essaouira / Marrakech. UNESCO inscribed 2019.
Spiritual music tradition of sub-Saharan origin combining Islamic Sufi practices with pre-Islamic African traditions. Central to Lila healing ceremonies. Instruments: guembri (three-string bass lute), qraqeb (metal castanets), tbel (large drum). Contexts: ritual, festival, private.

### Ahwach (أحواش)
Category: Dance. Origin: High Atlas / Anti-Atlas.
Collective Amazigh dance-poetry tradition featuring call-and-response between male and female groups. Performed at community celebrations. Instruments: bendir, talount, voice.

### Ahidous (أحيدوس)
Category: Dance. Origin: Middle Atlas.
Amazigh collective dance from Middle Atlas. Dancers form shoulder-to-shoulder lines, accompanied by poetry and percussion. Instruments: bendir, alloun, voice.

### Dakka Marrakchia (دقة مراكشية)
Category: Music. Origin: Marrakech.
High-energy percussion ensemble featuring copper drums, cymbals, and call-and-response vocals. Instruments: taârija, naqus, voice.

### Aita (عيطة)
Category: Music. Origin: Atlantic Plains.
Traditional sung poetry addressing themes of love, separation, and rural life. Performed by chikhates. Instruments: kamanja, oud, darbuka.

### Malhun (الملحون)
Category: Music. Origin: Fez / Meknes.
Classical Moroccan sung poetry tradition. Sophisticated lyrics on love, religion, and society. Originated in urban craft guilds. Instruments: oud, swisen, darbuka.

### Andalusi (الأندلسي)
Category: Classical. Origin: Fez / Tetouan.
Classical Moroccan music descended from Moorish Andalusia (Al-Andalus). Highly codified suite structure (nawba). Instruments: oud, rabab, kamanja, darbuka.

### Rwais (الرايس)
Category: Music. Origin: Souss.
Amazigh poet-musician tradition from the Souss region. Master musicians (rais) perform epic narratives. Instruments: ribab, lotar, voice.

### Chaabi (شعبي)
Category: Popular. Origin: Urban Morocco.
Popular music form drawing from malhun, aita, and other traditions. Accessible style for weddings and celebrations.

## Key Artists

### Gnawa Masters
Maalem Mahmoud Guinea (1951–2015) — Essaouira. Greatest Gnawa musician of all time.
Maalem Mustapha Bakbou — Essaouira. Traditional ceremonial Gnawa preservationist.
Maalem Hassan Boussou — Marrakech. International collaborations.
Maalem Abdelkebir Merchane — Tangier. Northern Morocco Gnawa bridge.
Maalem Seddik El Arch — Meknes. Keeper of Meknes Gnawa lineage.
Maalem Allal Soudani — Fez. Guardian of Fassi Gnawa traditions.
Hamid El Kasri — Ksar El Kebir. Powerful vocals, ceremonial expertise.
Hassan Hakmoun — Marrakech/New York. Gnawa fusion pioneer, sintir virtuoso.
Majid Bekkas — Salé. Gnawa-jazz innovator, plays guembri/oud/guitar.

### Folk-Rock Pioneers
Nass El Ghiwane (1971) — Casablanca. "The Rolling Stones of Africa." Protest music.
Jil Jilala (1972) — Casablanca. Sufi-influenced rock.
Lemchaheb (1973) — Casablanca. Third legendary folk-rock band.

### Amazigh Artists
Fatima Tabaamrant — Souss. Most famous female Rwais artist. Amazigh language champion.
Groupe Izenzaren (1972) — Agadir. Pioneering Amazigh rock.
Groupe Oudaden (1978) — Agadir. Influential Amazigh rock.
Rais Said Outajajt — Tiznit. Legendary Rwais poet-musician.

### Other Notable Artists
Hajja El Hamdaouia (1930–2015) — Casablanca. Queen of Aita, legendary chaabi voice.
Najat Aatabou — Khemisset. Women's issues through music.
Hmaoui Hmidou — Marrakech. Dakka Marrakchia percussion master.

## Instruments
Guembri: 3-string bass lute, camel-skin body. Central to Gnawa.
Qraqeb: Metal castanets (iron). Gnawa percussion.
Bendir: Frame drum with snare strings. Ahwach, Ahidous.
Oud: Short-neck lute. Andalusi, Malhun.
Kamanja: Spike fiddle. Aita, Andalusi.
Rabab: Bowed string, goat skin. Andalusi, Amazigh.
Tbel: Large double-headed drum. Gnawa processions.
Darbuka: Goblet drum, ceramic or metal. Pan-Moroccan.
Taârija: Small goblet drum. Dakka Marrakchia.
Naqus: Metal bell/cymbal. Dakka Marrakchia.
Lotar: Small lute. Amazigh music.
Ribab: Bowed mono-string. Rwais.

## Major Festivals
Gnaoua World Music Festival — Essaouira. Annual, June. Founded 1998. International Gnawa showcase.
Fes Festival of World Sacred Music — Fez. Annual, June. Founded 1994. Sacred music from worldwide traditions.
Mawazine Rhythms of the World — Rabat. Annual, June. Founded 2001. Largest music festival in Africa.
Timitar Festival — Agadir. Annual, July. Founded 2004. Amazigh music and international acts.
Tanjazz Festival — Tangier. Annual, September. Founded 2000. Jazz festival.
Festival of Sufi Culture — Fez. Annual. Founded 2007. Sufi traditions.

## Cities
Essaouira — Spiritual home of Gnawa music. Gnaoua World Music Festival.
Marrakech — Hub for Dakka Marrakchia. Diverse performance scene.
Fez — Cradle of Andalusi and Malhun. Fes Sacred Music Festival.
Casablanca — Birthplace of Nass El Ghiwane and folk-rock movement.
Agadir — Centre of Amazigh rock and Souss musical traditions.
Tangier — Jazz scene, northern Gnawa traditions.
Meknes — Malhun tradition, Meknes Gnawa lineage.

## API Endpoints
All return JSON with CORS headers:
- /api/knowledge/artists.json — All artists with biography, forms, city
- /api/knowledge/forms.json — All performance traditions with instruments, UNESCO status
- /api/knowledge/instruments.json — All instruments with type, family, associated forms
- /api/knowledge/festivals.json — All festivals with city, forms, founded year
- /api/knowledge/facts.json — Key facts for AI citation

## Citation Format
Music in Morocco (2026). [Topic]. https://musicinmorocco.com/[path]
Published by Slow Morocco · https://www.slowmorocco.com
